title: Which of Lapland's magical countries is best - Finland, Sweden or Norway?
text:
Lapland's winter wonderland spans three countries, each with their own qualities. Here's how to choose between them

Lapland: a mystical, snow-whipped Arctic expanse; a land so esoteric that a survey last year found almost a third of British respondents believe it to be fictional. You’d be forgiven, too, for not knowing that this boomerang-shaped region takes in not one but three Scandanivan countries – the far northern clutches of Norway, Sweden and Finland.

Booking a holiday to Lapland, therefore, is as much a question of unpicking these neighbouring cultures and landscapes as it would be for a foreigner choosing between England, Ireland, Scotland and Wales.

All of Lapland is blanketed in magic, under the spell of the Northern Lights and roamed by the indingeous Sámi people and their reindeer, but each has its own allure; be it Finland and its status as the world capital of Christmas, Sweden, home to the original Icehotel, or Norway, land of the fjords. Here is a breakdown to help you pick the right Lapland for you.
